definition: **Crossing over** is the process during meiosis in which <u>two homologous chromosomes exchange genetic material</u>. It occurs in <u>prophase I</u> when <u>non-sister chromatids</u> of a homologous pair swap segments of DNA. Crossing over creates new allele combinations on each chromosome, contributing to <u>genetic diversity</u> in the gametes.
tips: Crossing over happens between <u>homologous chromosomes</u> (for example, between the chromosome 1 from mom and the chromosome 1 from dad). It does **not** occur between <u>sister chromatids</u> of the same chromosome (sisters are identical, so exchanging between them would change nothing).
The physical evidence of crossing over is the <u>chiasma</u> (pl. chiasmata), which is the <u>X-shaped connection</u> where homologous chromatids have exchanged pieces.

Crossing over is one reason why siblings (except identical twins) are <u>genetically unique</u>. It shuffles genes - even genes on the same chromosome can be reshuffled if crossing over happens between them.
exam_appearance: If a question asks about sources of genetic variation in meiosis, crossing over is a key answer (along with independent assortment). For example, "Name one event in meiosis that increases genetic variability" -> <u>crossing over in prophase I</u>.

You might see a diagram of paired chromosomes with segments swapped - identifying that process as crossing over (or "homologous recombination") is essential. Also, problems on genetic linkage and mapping rely on understanding that <u>crossing over frequency between two genes indicates their distance apart</u>.
